metadata.notes: A Holy Week sermon focusing on the Ransom theory of atonement and the authority of Scripture.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher uses CP to dismiss modern media and 'literal-minded' people. There is a clear 'must' regarding how to interpret faith (only through Scripture).
quotes: it must be rooted and grounded in Scripture
people persist in constructing a Jesus to suit themselves
the movie offers a mere two hours... whereas the Bible summons us to a whole lifetime of study

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: Nurturing Parent appears in the latter half, offering comfort to those feeling vulnerable or 'in a prison.'
quotes: if you have any sense of your own vulnerability... then this coming of the Son of Man is for you

adult.analysis: The preacher engages in significant Adult data processing, analyzing historical transcripts, carbon dating, and linguistic metaphors (ransom vs. invasion).
quotes: Let's try a little exercise. Substitute the words...
The basic idea is this: i. A person or group has come under the control of another power.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher uses 'we' to force the congregation into a position of guilt (AC), claiming 'we shouted Crucify him!'
quotes: It forces us to see that our participation was not benign.

free_child_FC.analysis: Limited FC; the joy is 'defiant confidence' rather than spontaneous play, though the use of Narnia and Churchill shows some creative flair.

transaction_analysis.primary_transaction_style: Adult -> Adult (Teaching) with Ulterior Parent -> Child (Correcting)
transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher primarily uses Adult logic to explain theology but switches to Parent when addressing the listener's 'misdirected' feelings or 'futile' modern habits.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Socially: 'Let's study this text.' Psychologically: 'You are wrong to like that movie; listen to my authority.'
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'Bait' is the intellectual exercise; the 'Switch' is the imposition of collective guilt for the crucifixion.

detected_games.name: ITHY (I'm Only Trying To Help You)

formula_g_analysis.con: I will explain the 'true' meaning of Jesus that movies can't give you.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's desire for 'spiritual experiences' or intellectual clarity.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The preacher moves from teacher to recruiter for an 'underground army' of suffering.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels inadequate for liking the movie and burdened by the 'army' call.

evidence_quotes: I wish I had had the presence of mind to tell her that I would go to the movie if she would come back to the Bible study group.

detected_games.name: NIGYSOB

formula_g_analysis.con: Let's look at the Shroud of Turin/Movies.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Dismissing these as 'relics' and 'two-dimensional' compared to the preacher's 'Scripture'.

evidence_quotes: people persist in constructing a Jesus to suit themselves.

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: Authenticity is maintained when the preacher admits the metaphors 'don't make earthly sense,' moving into a transparent Adult admission of the limits of language.

preacher_roles.rescuer: High: Offers the 'only' way to understand Jesus through Scripture to save the listener from 'futile ways.'
preacher_roles.persecutor: Medium: Judges those who find meaning in the Kazantzakis movie or relics.
preacher_roles.victim: Low: Slight hint of the 'unappreciated teacher' when mentioning the woman who dropped out of Bible study.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim (hostages to Sin/Death) or Persecutor (the ones who shouted 'Crucify him').
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: The sermon moves toward autonomy by inviting the listener to join the 'resistance,' though this is still framed within a military hierarchy.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon is intellectually robust (Adult) but psychologically heavy. It utilizes the 'Ransom' metaphor to create a sense of debt and obligation. While it offers comfort, it does so by first enforcing a 'Victim' status on the listener (hostage to Sin) and then a 'Persecutor' status (killer of Christ). The dismissal of the parishioner's movie experience is a classic Parent-Child 'put-down' that undermines the listener's subjective experience in favor of the preacher's dogmatic boundaries.
strengths: Strong Adult engagement with text and history.
Avoids 'smothering' Nurturing Parent by emphasizing the difficulty of the task.
areas_for_improvement: High Critical Parent when discussing modern culture.
Use of collective guilt ('We shouted Crucify him') can trigger unhealthy Adapted Child responses.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Try to validate the 'Free Child's' spiritual experience in movies or art before moving to Adult correction. Avoid 'buttonholing' parishioners with 'I'll do X if you do Y' transactions, which are conditional and manipulative.
